awd_titl_txt: Planning: IUPUI Plan for Center for Equity in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The Center for Equity in Engineering (CEE) planning project at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) will develop a plan to establish an NSF-supported CEE to broaden participation of students, faculty, and staff of diverse backgrounds in the Purdue School of Engineering & Technology (PSET). The CEE will be planned with the input of internal and external stakeholders to innovatively transform PSET by growing the enrollment of underrepresented (UR) students, including women, ethnic minorities, veterans, and students with disabilities, as well as by promoting their retention, timely graduation, and future success. The proposed CEE will strongly magnify the enrollment, graduation and career success of UR students in Indiana, the Midwest, and nationwide, particularly by expanding PSET’s ongoing sharing of best practices with other urban-serving engineering schools. CEE planning will strengthen engagement with local high-schools and organizations that serve UR populations. A successful CEE will have enormous impact on UR participation in STEM-based careers and may provide Midwest industries in particular with a much more diversified and broader talent base. Improved learning pedagogies and the organizational, cultural, and structural changes driven by the CEE will benefit students of all backgrounds in their engineering careers. The CEE will widely share knowledge about best practices in broadening participation in engineering through PSET’s existing and new partnerships with other engineering schools nationally, as well as through other dissemination outlets.

PSET is on an innovative urban campus in a city that has rapidly diversified its population, supporting a highly industrialized State economy increasingly in need of a trained engineering workforce. IUPUI has been nationally recognized for assessment and learning innovations, first-year experiences and learning communities, and commitment to the UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). IUPUI has vigorous Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI)-focused efforts that are yielding positive outcomes. PSET at IUPUI offers numerous accredited programs as pathways to engineering-related careers and has notable DEI accomplishments in recent years, including strongly increasing its enrollment of women and students of color. CEE planning activities will leverage PSET’s newly published 2021 DEI Plan, which is aligned around four diversity indicators: I) Viability and Vitality; II) Education and Scholarship; III) Climate and Intergroup Relations; and IV) Access and Success. PSET has strived to adopt and subsequently apply these four diversity indicators, as defined by Dr. Daryl Smith’s book: Diversity’s Promise for Higher Education: Making it Work, as an organizational framework for PSET’s DEI strategic plan and a substrate for CEE planning activities. PSET will utilize four existing task forces aligned with each of these diversity indicators, which include students, faculty, staff, alumni, corporate partners, and additional community representatives and friends. Moreover, IUPUI’s framework to support the UN SDGs, as well as other institutional structures and programs and external relationships, will be incorporated into the CEE planning process. An improved first-year curriculum could feature the SDGs as a motivating force for diverse students to study and succeed in engineering. The CEE ultimately aims to strengthen students’ engineering identity, self-efficacy, and social capital, while building community to dispel explicit or implicit biases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
The Purdue School of Engineering & Technology (PSET) at Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis (IUPUI) sought to develop a plan for a Center for Engineering Equity (CEE). The proposal built upon PSET’s 2021 Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) 5-year Plan, framed on the four diversity indicators of Daryl Smith’s Diversity’s Promise for Higher Education: Making It Work. The work envisioned enacting change across four dimensions – cultural, educational, structural, and pedagogical – and drew upon existing strengths and infrastructure in both PSET and IUPUI. These included a Peer-Led Team Learning (PLTL) program that strongly benefited underrepresented students, robust campus-wide Summer Bridge and First-Year Seminar programs, an Equity Champions program, and IUPUI’s recognition for supporting UN Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). The CEE was expected to engage the diverse motivations of first-year engineering and technology students through SDG-centered projects, and to expand the role of PLTL in both cultivating leaders and improving the success of all students.

Shortly after the planning grant was awarded in June 2022, the presidents of Indiana University and Purdue University announced a plan to split up IUPUI and dissolve PSET, thus eliminating its DEI strategic plan and its recruiting strategies and pathways. In 2024, three colleges of Purdue University West Lafayette (PUWL) absorbed the remaining faculty and staff associated with prior PSET programs, which would be gradually sunset. These colleges instead extended selected PUWL programs to Indianapolis starting with 1st year students. In these intervening two years, the grant team sought to understand the greatly altered emerging context, and to build new connections with partners and pathways in this new organizational structure to help carry this work forward.  Also complicating this work was the new Indiana Senate Enrolled Act No. 202, mandating that any committees, programs, or initiatives supporting diversity at public higher education institutions in Indiana must foster intellectual as well as cultural diversity and, among other provisions, required disciplinary action against faculty members who are “unlikely” to act in certain ways that the Act promotes.

The original planning goals for a CEE led by the Dean of PSET were replaced by planning goals related to broadening participation and demographics of the relevant Purdue colleges. The team spent considerable time and effort apprising Purdue higher administration about the CEE opportunity, and seeking alignment with Purdue’s vision and strategic plans. The team won a seed grant from Purdue University to extend this effort. Through this process, it was determined that a substantially new planning process was needed for a CEE for Purdue engineering and technology programs in Indianapolis, because (a) the opportunity for impact is at a much larger scale due to new enrollment goals and investments, (b) the admission criteria and time-to-graduation metrics used by PUWL would result in a substantially different demographic distribution than the previous PSET criteria and metrics, and (c) the new administrative structure embeds Purdue’s Indianapolis programs within the much larger PUWL colleges, requiring a planning process that builds their support. In particular, with many Indiana students no longer having PSET paths to a Purdue engineering degree, PUWL may have to build new pathways to broaden participation in engineering in Indianapolis, including various transfer pathways.

What has not changed is the opportunity for a more innovative urban campus in a city that has rapidly diversified its population, supporting a highly industrialized state economy in need of a diverse engineering workforce. IUPUI’s nationally recognized assessment and learning innovations, first-year experiences and learning communities, and commitment to the UN SDGs have been retained at Indiana University Indianapolis (IUI), which remains physically proximate to Purdue’s Indianapolis programs, with opportunities to collaborate.

During the planning grant period, the team assessed historical student demographics and success factors at both IUPUI and PUWL that a future CEE must consider. The team also conducted a survey and focus group interviews of current students to ascertain their views on success factors. Our primary outcomes are demographic data on student persistence and graduation; input from focus groups of graduating engineering seniors; information about existing and proposed Purdue efforts to support broadening participation in engineering (BPE); and an annotated bibliography of literature on strategies and initiatives supporting persistence and success in STEM, especially in Indiana.

This work has generated information that we anticipate disseminating via conference or journal articles within the next two years, including (a) demographics, persistence, and graduation of applicants who were directly admitted to Engineering compared to those admitted to IUPUI’s University College (seeking but not qualified for direct admission to Engineering), (b) focus group interviews with graduating seniors in engineering at IUPUI and with historical employers of IUPUI engineering graduates, and (c) Purdue initiatives supporting BPE that are likely to support the launch of a center for engineering equity in Indianapolis.


Last Modified: 02/24/2025
Modified by: Mohamed Razi Nalim
por.por_txt_cntn:

The proposal built upon PSETs 2021 Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) 5-year Plan, framed on the four diversity indicators of Daryl SmithsDiversitys Promise for Higher Education: Making It Work. The CEE was expected to engage the diverse motivations of first-year engineering and technology students through SDG-centered projects, and to expand the role of PLTL in both cultivating leaders and improving the success of all students.

The original planning goals for a CEE led by the Dean of PSET were replaced by planning goals related to broadening participation and demographics of the relevant Purdue colleges. Through this process, it was determined that a substantially new planning process was needed for a CEE for Purdue engineering and technology programs in Indianapolis, because (a) the opportunity for impact is at a much larger scale due to new enrollment goals and investments, (b) the admission criteria and time-to-graduation metrics used by PUWL would result in a substantially different demographic distribution than the previous PSET criteria and metrics, and (c) the new administrative structure embeds Purdues Indianapolis programs within the much larger PUWL colleges, requiring a planning process that builds their support. In particular, with many Indiana students no longer having PSET paths to a Purdue engineering degree, PUWL may have to build new pathways to broaden participation in engineering in Indianapolis, including various transfer pathways.

Our primary outcomes are demographic data on student persistence and graduation; input from focus groups of graduating engineering seniors; information about existing and proposed Purdue efforts to support broadening participation in engineering (BPE); and an annotated bibliography of literature on strategies and initiatives supporting persistence and success in STEM, especially in Indiana.


This work has generated information that we anticipate disseminating via conference or journal articles within the next two years, including (a) demographics, persistence, and graduation of applicants who were directly admitted to Engineering compared to those admitted to IUPUIs University College (seeking but not qualified for direct admission to Engineering), (b) focus group interviews with graduating seniors in engineering at IUPUI and with historical employers of IUPUI engineering graduates, and (c) Purdue initiatives supporting BPE that are likely to support the launch of a center for engineering equity in Indianapolis.
